summary: This is a Law360 news article reporting that the U.S. Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility has opened an investigation into potential misconduct by DOJ attorneys during the negotiation of Jeffrey Epstein's 2008 plea deal. The investigation was prompted by Senator Ben Sasse following the Miami Herald's 'Perversion of Justice' series, which detailed how the deal was crafted and allegedly excluded victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy individual who received a controversial plea deal in 2008 for charges involving solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution, spending 13 months in prison.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.context: Republican Senator from Nebraska and member of the Senate Judiciary Committee who repeatedly pushed for and prompted the DOJ investigation into the Epstein plea deal misconduct allegations.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Former U.S. attorney for the Southern District of Florida who, according to the Miami Herald report, worked with other DOJ attorneys and defense lawyers to craft Epstein's lenient 2008 plea deal.

persons.name: Patty Murray
persons.context: Democratic Senator from Washington who led a group of senators in December urging the DOJ's inspector general to investigate potential misconduct related to the Epstein plea deal.

persons.name: Tim Kaine
persons.context: Democratic Senator from Virginia who joined Senator Patty Murray in urging an investigation into potential misconduct related to the Epstein plea deal.

persons.name: Lauren Berg
persons.context: Author of the Law360 article reporting on the DOJ investigation into the Epstein plea deal.

persons.name: Adam Lidgett
persons.context: Provided additional reporting for the Law360 article.

persons.name: Carolina Bolado
persons.context: Provided additional reporting for the Law360 article.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. attorney, worked with DOJ attorneys and Epstein's defense team to craft the 2008 plea deal for Epstein.
Senator Sasse pushed for and prompted the DOJ investigation into the misconduct allegations surrounding Epstein's plea deal, calling Epstein a 'child rapist'.
Senators Murray and Kaine led a group of Democratic senators in urging the DOJ inspector general to investigate the Epstein plea deal.

events.title: Epstein Plea Deal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to charges involving solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution, receiving a lenient sentence of 13 months in prison following a deal crafted by DOJ attorneys and defense lawyers.

events.title: Miami Herald 'Perversion of Justice' Series
events.description: The Miami Herald published a three-part investigative series detailing how Epstein's alleged victims were deliberately excluded from the 2008 plea deal, prompting political response.

events.title: Senators Urge DOJ IG Investigation
events.description: A group of Democratic senators led by Patty Murray and Tim Kaine urged the DOJ's inspector general to investigate potential misconduct related to the Epstein-Acosta plea deal, concerned it may have flouted the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

events.title: DOJ Announces OPR Investigation
events.description: The U.S. Department of Justice informed Senator Ben Sasse that its Office of Professional Responsibility had opened an investigation into allegations of misconduct by DOJ attorneys during the resolution of the Epstein case.

events.title: Epstein Settles Victim Lawsuit
events.description: Epstein settled a dispute with the attorney who represented his teenage victims, avoiding a trial that was to have featured testimony from the women.

keyFacts: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility opened an investigation into potential misconduct by DOJ attorneys during the negotiation of Jeffrey Epstein's 2008 plea deal.
The investigation was prompted by Senator Ben Sasse after reading the Miami Herald's 'Perversion of Justice' series, which alleged victims were excluded from the deal.
The 2008 plea deal involved then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta and other DOJ attorneys working with Epstein's defense team; Epstein pled guilty to prostitution-related charges and served 13 months.
A group of Democratic senators separately urged the DOJ's inspector general to investigate the deal in December 2018, concerned it violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
Epstein settled a lawsuit with his victims' attorney in December 2018, avoiding a trial where the women would have testified.
